Use the above equivalence to prove we have a limit.

type:
‚àÄ {J : Type w} {C : Type u} [inst : CategoryTheory.Category.{v, u} C] {B : C}

  CategoryTheory.Limits.HasLimit F

The theorem asserts that the sum of the infinite geometric series $\sum\_{n=0}^{\infty} r^n$ equals $\frac{1}{1 - r}$ for $0 \leq r < 1$.

type: ‚àÄ {r : NNReal}, r < 1 ‚Üí HasSum (fun n => r ^ n) (1 - r)‚Åª¬π
name: NNReal.hasSum_geometric
docString: The theorem asserts that the sum of the infinite geometric series $\sum\_{n=0}^{\infty} r^n$ equals $\frac{1}{1 - r}$ for $0 \leq r < 1$.

This theorem states that for any real number `r` whose absolute value is less than one, the sequence `n * r^n` tends to zero as `n` approaches infinity. In other words, as `n` becomes larger and larger, the value of `n * r^n` gets closer and closer to zero. This is a common result in analysis related to the behavior of geometric sequences.

type: ‚àÄ {r : ‚Ñù}, |r| < 1 ‚Üí Filter.Tendsto (fun n => ‚Üën * r ^ n) Filter.atTop (nhds 0)
name: tendsto_self_mul_const_pow_of_abs_lt_one
docString: This theorem states that for any real number `r` whose absolute value is less than one, the sequence `n * r^n` tends to zero as `n` approaches infinity. In other words, as `n` becomes larger and larger, the value of `n * r^n` gets closer and closer to zero. This is a common result in analysis related to the behavior of geometric sequences.

There is an irrational number `r` between any two reals `x < r < y`.

type: ‚àÄ {x y : ‚Ñù}, x < y ‚Üí ‚àÉ r, Irrational r ‚àß x < r ‚àß r < y
name: exists_irrational_btwn
docString: There is an irrational number `r` between any two reals `x < r < y`.

For any extended nonnegative real number `r`, the infinite geometric series $\sum\_{n=0}^{\infty} r^n$ converges to $\frac{1}{1-r}$, with the value being a finite number if $r < 1$ and infinity if $r \ge 1$.

type: ‚àÄ (r : ENNReal), ‚àë' (n : ‚Ñï), r ^ n = (1 - r)‚Åª¬π
name: ENNReal.tsum_geometric
docString: For any extended nonnegative real number `r`, the infinite geometric series $\sum\_{n=0}^{\infty} r^n$ converges to $\frac{1}{1-r}$, with the value being a finite number if $r < 1$ and infinity if $r \ge 1$.

This theorem states that for any nonnegative real number `r` less than one, the sequence `r^n` tends to zero as `n` tends to infinity. In other words, as `n` increases without bound, the values of `r^n` get arbitrarily close to zero. This is a formalization of the mathematical result that a geometric sequence with a common ratio in the open interval `(0, 1)` converges to zero.

type: ‚àÄ {r : NNReal}, r < 1 ‚Üí Filter.Tendsto (fun n => r ^ n) Filter.atTop (nhds 0)
name: NNReal.tendsto_pow_atTop_nhds_zero_of_lt_one
docString: This theorem states that for any nonnegative real number `r` less than one, the sequence `r^n` tends to zero as `n` tends to infinity. In other words, as `n` increases without bound, the values of `r^n` get arbitrarily close to zero. This is a formalization of the mathematical result that a geometric sequence with a common ratio in the open interval `(0, 1)` converges to zero.

For a real `r > 1` we have `n = o(r ^ n)` as `n ‚Üí ‚àû`.

Induction principle for intervals of real numbers: if a proposition `P` is true
on `[x‚ÇÄ, r * x‚ÇÄ)` and if `P` for `[x‚ÇÄ, r^n * x‚ÇÄ)` implies `P` for `[r^n * x‚ÇÄ, r^(n+1) * x‚ÇÄ)`,
then `P` is true for all `x ‚â• x‚ÇÄ`.

type:
‚àÄ {P : ‚Ñù ‚Üí Prop} (x‚ÇÄ r : ‚Ñù),
  1 < r ‚Üí
    0 < x‚ÇÄ ‚Üí
      (‚àÄ x ‚àà Set.Ico x‚ÇÄ (r * x‚ÇÄ), P x) ‚Üí
        (‚àÄ n ‚â• 1, (‚àÄ z ‚àà Set.Ico x‚ÇÄ (r ^ n * x‚ÇÄ), P z) ‚Üí ‚àÄ z ‚àà Set.Ico (r ^ n * x‚ÇÄ) (r ^ (n + 1) * x‚ÇÄ), P z) ‚Üí
          ‚àÄ x ‚â• x‚ÇÄ, P x
name: Real.induction_Ico_mul
docString:
Induction principle for intervals of real numbers: if a proposition `P` is true
on `[x‚ÇÄ, r * x‚ÇÄ)` and if `P` for `[x‚ÇÄ, r^n * x‚ÇÄ)` implies `P` for `[r^n * x‚ÇÄ, r^(n+1) * x‚ÇÄ)`,
then `P` is true for all `x ‚â• x‚ÇÄ`.

        ‚àÄ {a : Œ±}, Filter.Tendsto f Filter.atTop (nhds a) ‚Üí ‚àÄ (n : ‚Ñï), dist (f n) a ‚â§ C * r ^ n / (1 - r)

type:
‚àÄ {ùïú : Type u_1} {E : Type u_2} {F : Type u_3} [inst : NontriviallyNormedField ùïú] [inst_1 : NormedAddCommGroup E]

**Cauchy-Goursat theorem** for an annulus. If `f : ‚ÑÇ ‚Üí E` is continuous on the closed annulus
`r ‚â§ ‚Äñz - c‚Äñ ‚â§ R`, `0 < r ‚â§ R`, and is complex differentiable at all but countably many points of
its interior, then the integrals of `f` over the circles `‚Äñz - c‚Äñ = r` and `‚Äñz - c‚Äñ = R` are equal
to each other.

type:
‚àÄ {E : Type u} [inst : NormedAddCommGroup E] [inst_1 : NormedSpace ‚ÑÇ E] [inst_2 : CompleteSpace E] {c : ‚ÑÇ} {r R : ‚Ñù},
  0 < r ‚Üí
    r ‚â§ R ‚Üí
      ‚àÄ {f : ‚ÑÇ ‚Üí E} {s : Set ‚ÑÇ},
        Set.Countable s ‚Üí
          ContinuousOn f (Metric.closedBall c R \ Metric.ball c r) ‚Üí
            (‚àÄ z ‚àà (Metric.ball c R \ Metric.closedBall c r) \ s, DifferentiableAt ‚ÑÇ f z) ‚Üí
              (‚àÆ (z : ‚ÑÇ) in C(c, R), f z) = ‚àÆ (z : ‚ÑÇ) in C(c, r), f z
name: Complex.circleIntegral_eq_of_differentiable_on_annulus_off_countable
docString:
**Cauchy-Goursat theorem** for an annulus. If `f : ‚ÑÇ ‚Üí E` is continuous on the closed annulus
`r ‚â§ ‚Äñz - c‚Äñ ‚â§ R`, `0 < r ‚â§ R`, and is complex differentiable at all but countably many points of
its interior, then the integrals of `f` over the circles `‚Äñz - c‚Äñ = r` and `‚Äñz - c‚Äñ = R` are equal
to each other.

The radius of a formal multilinear series is equal to
$\liminf_{n\to\infty} \frac{1}{\sqrt[n]{‚Äñp n‚Äñ}}$. The actual statement uses `‚Ñù‚â•0` and some
coercions.

type:
‚àÄ {ùïú : Type u_1} [inst : NontriviallyNormedField ùïú] {E : Type u_2} [inst_1 : NormedAddCommGroup E]
  [inst_2 : NormedSpace ùïú E] {F : Type u_3} [inst_3 : NormedAddCommGroup F] [inst_4 : NormedSpace ùïú F]
  (p : FormalMultilinearSeries ùïú E F),
  FormalMultilinearSeries.radius p = Filter.liminf (fun n => 1 / ‚Üë(‚Äñp n‚Äñ‚Çä ^ (1 / ‚Üën))) Filter.atTop
name: FormalMultilinearSeries.radius_eq_liminf
docString:
The radius of a formal multilinear series is equal to
$\liminf_{n\to\infty} \frac{1}{\sqrt[n]{‚Äñp n‚Äñ}}$. The actual statement uses `‚Ñù‚â•0` and some
coercions.

`sqrt z` is the square root of an integer `z`. If `z` is positive, it returns the largest
integer `r` such that `r * r ‚â§ n`. If it is negative, it returns `0`. For example, `sqrt (-1) = 0`,
`sqrt 1 = 1`, `sqrt 2 = 1`

type: ‚Ñ§ ‚Üí ‚Ñ§
name: Int.sqrt
docString:
`sqrt z` is the square root of an integer `z`. If `z` is positive, it returns the largest
integer `r` such that `r * r ‚â§ n`. If it is negative, it returns `0`. For example, `sqrt (-1) = 0`,
`sqrt 1 = 1`, `sqrt 2 = 1`

(Impl) Show that the raised cone is a limit.

type:
{J : Type v} ‚Üí
  [inst : CategoryTheory.SmallCategory J] ‚Üí
    {C : Type u} ‚Üí
      [inst_1 : CategoryTheory.Category.{v, u} C] ‚Üí
        [inst_2 : CategoryTheory.IsConnected J] ‚Üí
          {B : C} ‚Üí
            {F : CategoryTheory.Functor J (CategoryTheory.Over B)} ‚Üí
              {c : CategoryTheory.Limits.Cone (CategoryTheory.Functor.comp F (CategoryTheory.Over.forget B))} ‚Üí
                CategoryTheory.Limits.IsLimit c ‚Üí
                  CategoryTheory.Limits.IsLimit (CategoryTheory.Over.CreatesConnected.raiseCone c)
name: CategoryTheory.Over.CreatesConnected.raisedConeIsLimit
docString: (Impl) Show that the raised cone is a limit.
